tasks.title: Clean filter
tasks.note: Most dishwashers have a filter that traps food particles and other debris. It's essential to clean the filter regularly, at least once a month or every two months. To clean the filter, remove it from the dishwasher and rinse it under running water to remove any debris. If the filter is particularly dirty, you can soak it in a solution of warm water and dish soap before rinsing it.

tasks.title: Clean the spray arm
tasks.note: The spray arm is responsible for distributing water and detergent throughout the dishwasher. Over time, it can become clogged with food particles and other debris. To clean the spray arm, remove it from the dishwasher and rinse it under running water. You can also use a toothbrush or a small wire brush to scrub away any buildup.

tasks.title: Check the dishwasher's seals
tasks.note: The seals around the dishwasher door can become dirty or worn over time. Check the seals regularly and wipe them clean with a damp cloth if necessary. If you notice any cracks or damage to the seals, they may need to be replaced.

tasks.title: Run a dishwasher cleaner
tasks.note: You can use a dishwasher cleaner to remove any buildup or odors inside your dishwasher. Run the dishwasher empty and follow the instructions on the cleaner's packaging.

tasks.title: Clean the coils
tasks.note: The coils on the back or bottom of your refrigerator can become dirty and dusty, which can reduce their efficiency. Clean the coils at least once or twice a year with a vacuum cleaner or a coil brush.

tasks.title: Check the door gaskets
tasks.note: The door gaskets on your refrigerator can become dirty or damaged, which can cause cold air to escape and increase your energy bills. Check the gaskets regularly and clean them with a damp cloth if necessary. If you notice any cracks or damage, replace the gaskets.

tasks.title: Clean interior
tasks.note: Clean the inside of your refrigerator regularly, ideally once a week, with a solution of warm water and baking soda. This will help remove any odors and prevent the growth of mold and bacteria.

tasks.title: Check the temperature
tasks.note: The ideal temperature for a refrigerator is between 35 and 38 degrees Fahrenheit. Use a thermometer to check the temperature regularly and adjust the settings if necessary.

tasks.title: Replace water filter
tasks.note: If your refrigerator has a water filter, replace it every 6 months or according to manufacturer recommendations. A dirty filter can affect water taste and quality.

tasks.title: Clean the detergent dispenser
tasks.note: The detergent dispenser can become dirty and clogged with detergent and fabric softener residue. Clean the dispenser regularly with warm water and a soft brush or toothbrush.

tasks.title: Check the hoses
tasks.note: Check the hoses that supply water to your washing machine for any signs of wear, cracks or leaks. Replace them if necessary, and make sure they are not kinked or twisted to allow for proper water flow.

tasks.title: Run a cleaning cycle
tasks.note: Run a cleaning cycle on your washing machine at least once a month using a washing machine cleaner. This will help remove any buildup of detergent, fabric softener and other residues that can cause odor, mold and mildew.

tasks.title: Clean the gasket and door
tasks.note: Clean the rubber gasket around the door and the door itself to prevent mold and mildew buildup. Pay special attention to the bottom of the gasket where water can collect.

tasks.title: Clean the lint filter
tasks.note: The lint filter should be cleaned after every use to prevent the buildup of lint, which can reduce the efficiency of the dryer and pose a fire hazard. Simply remove the lint filter from the dryer and remove any lint with your fingers or a soft brush.

tasks.title: Clean the vent duct
tasks.note: The vent duct carries hot air and moisture outside your home. Over time, it can become clogged with lint and other debris, which can reduce the efficiency of the dryer and pose a fire hazard. Clean the vent duct at least once a year using a vent cleaning brush or hire a professional to do it for you.

tasks.title: Check the exhaust hood
tasks.note: The exhaust hood should be located outside your home and can become clogged with debris, such as bird nests or leaves. Check the exhaust hood regularly and clean it if necessary.

tasks.title: Replace air filter
tasks.note: Replace the air filter every 1-3 months depending on usage and filter type. A dirty filter can reduce airflow and cause the system to work harder than necessary, leading to higher energy bills and potential breakdowns.

tasks.title: Clean outdoor unit
tasks.note: Clean the outdoor unit (condenser) by removing debris, leaves, and dirt from around the unit. Ensure at least 2 feet of clearance around the unit for proper airflow.

tasks.title: Schedule professional maintenance
tasks.note: Have a professional HVAC technician inspect and maintain your system twice a year - once before cooling season and once before heating season. They can perform comprehensive inspections, clean the system, and address any issues before they become major problems.

tasks.title: Check thermostat
tasks.note: Check your thermostat regularly to ensure it is functioning properly and calibrated correctly. Consider upgrading to a programmable or smart thermostat for better energy efficiency.

tasks.title: Drain and flush tank
tasks.note: Drain and flush the water heater tank annually to remove sediment buildup that can reduce efficiency and damage the tank. Turn off power/gas, let cool, attach hose to drain valve, and flush until water runs clear.

tasks.title: Test pressure relief valve
tasks.note: Test the temperature and pressure relief valve annually by lifting the lever to allow water to flow through the discharge tube. If no water flows or valve continues to leak after testing, replace it immediately.

tasks.title: Check anode rod
tasks.note: Inspect the anode rod every 2-3 years. This sacrificial rod prevents tank corrosion. If the rod is less than 1/2 inch thick or covered with calcium carbonate, replace it.

tasks.title: Insulate pipes
tasks.note: Insulate hot water pipes to reduce heat loss and save energy. This is especially important for the first 6 feet of pipes from the water heater.

tasks.title: Test alarms monthly
tasks.note: Test all smoke and carbon monoxide detectors monthly by pressing the test button. If the alarm doesn't sound or sounds weak, replace the battery immediately.

tasks.title: Replace batteries
tasks.note: Replace batteries in battery-powered detectors annually or when the low-battery chirp begins. Even hardwired detectors have backup batteries that need replacement.

tasks.title: Replace detectors
tasks.note: Replace smoke detectors every 10 years and carbon monoxide detectors every 5-7 years. Check manufacturer recommendations for your specific models.

tasks.title: Vacuum regularly
tasks.note: Vacuum your carpets at least once a week, or more frequently in high-traffic areas. Use a high-quality vacuum cleaner with strong suction and a HEPA filter to remove dirt, dust, and allergens from your carpets.

tasks.title: Deep clean professionally
tasks.note: Have carpets professionally cleaned every 12-18 months to remove deep-seated dirt and stains and refresh the appearance. This also helps maintain warranty coverage for many carpet types.

tasks.title: Spot clean spills immediately
tasks.note: Address spills and stains as soon as possible to prevent them from setting in. Blot up any excess liquid with a clean cloth, then use a spot cleaning solution and a clean cloth to gently remove the stain.

tasks.title: Sweep or vacuum regularly
tasks.note: Sweep or vacuum your hardwood floors at least weekly to remove dirt and debris. Use a soft-bristled broom or vacuum without a beater bar to avoid scratching the surface.

tasks.title: Clean with appropriate cleaner
tasks.note: Clean hardwood floors monthly with a cleaner specifically designed for your floor finish. Avoid using water, vinegar, or oil-based cleaners that can damage the finish.

tasks.title: Refinish floors
tasks.note: Refinish hardwood floors every 7-10 years depending on wear and traffic. Sand and apply new finish to restore beauty and protect the wood.

tasks.title: Clean windows
tasks.note: Clean your windows every 2-3 months to remove dirt and grime buildup. Use a mixture of water and mild detergent or window cleaner. Avoid using harsh chemicals or abrasive materials that can scratch or damage the glass.

tasks.title: Check weatherstripping
tasks.note: Inspect the weatherstripping around your windows annually to ensure that it is in good condition and sealing properly. Replace any worn or damaged weatherstripping to prevent drafts and improve energy efficiency.

tasks.title: Lubricate moving parts
tasks.note: Lubricate any moving parts on your windows, such as hinges or rollers, annually with a silicone spray lubricant. This will help keep the windows functioning smoothly and prevent damage to the hardware.

tasks.title: Clean gutters and downspouts
tasks.note: Clean your gutters and downspouts twice a year, in spring and fall, to remove debris such as leaves, twigs, and dirt. Use a gutter scoop or pressure washer. Always wear gloves and eye protection.

tasks.title: Inspect for damage
tasks.note: Inspect your gutters for signs of damage, such as cracks, holes, rust, or improper alignment. Address any issues promptly to prevent water damage to your home's foundation and roof.

tasks.title: Check gutter guards
tasks.note: If you have gutter guards installed, inspect and clean them annually to ensure they're functioning properly and not clogged with debris.

tasks.title: Inspect roof condition
tasks.note: Inspect your roof twice a year, especially after severe weather, for missing or damaged shingles, cracks, or signs of leaks. Use binoculars from the ground for safety.

tasks.title: Professional roof inspection
tasks.note: Have a professional roofer perform a comprehensive inspection every 3 years to identify potential issues before they become major problems. This is especially important for roofs over 10 years old.

tasks.title: Trim overhanging branches
tasks.note: Trim any tree branches that hang over the roof to prevent damage from falling limbs and leaves, and to reduce debris accumulation.

tasks.title: Check for leaks
tasks.note: Inspect all visible plumbing for leaks monthly. Check under sinks, around toilets, and near water heaters. Even small leaks can cause significant damage over time.

tasks.title: Test water pressure
tasks.note: Check water pressure throughout your home. Low pressure may indicate clogs or leaks, while high pressure can damage pipes and appliances.

tasks.title: Clean drains
tasks.note: Clean drain traps under sinks and remove hair and debris from shower and tub drains monthly to prevent clogs.

tasks.title: Winterize outdoor plumbing
tasks.note: Before first freeze, turn off outdoor water supply, drain hoses, and cover spigots with insulated covers to prevent pipe damage.

tasks.title: Test GFCI outlets
tasks.note: Test all GFCI outlets monthly by pressing the test button, then the reset button. If the outlet doesn't turn off and on properly, replace it immediately.

tasks.title: Check electrical panel
tasks.note: Inspect your electrical panel annually for signs of corrosion, burning smells, or warm spots. Ensure all breakers are properly labeled.

tasks.title: Professional electrical inspection
tasks.note: Have a licensed electrician inspect your electrical system every 10 years for homes under 40 years old, every 5 years for older homes.

tasks.title: Test safety features
tasks.note: Test the auto-reverse feature monthly by placing an object in the path of the closing door. The door should reverse immediately upon contact.

tasks.title: Lubricate moving parts
tasks.note: Lubricate the garage door's moving parts every 6 months, including rollers, hinges, and springs. Use a silicone-based lubricant for best results.

tasks.title: Inspect tracks and hardware
tasks.note: Inspect the tracks, springs, cables, and other hardware annually for signs of wear or damage. Do not attempt to repair springs yourself - call a professional.
